info.game_comments: (Sofia: Hi, this is Sofia of the Clue Crew.  Today, we give you a little taste of New York City.)

(1, 1).clue: Skaldic, a bit different than Eddaic poetry, originated in Norway, but was developed mainly on this island

(2, 1).clue: The city of Burlington lies on the shores of this, Vermont's largest lake

(4, 1).clue: (Sofia is on Park Avenue, enjoying a pretzel, when....)  Oops!  I forgot to get a side of this traditional yellow condiment

(5, 1).clue: Arsenic compounds are used as coloring agents in these sky displays

(6, 1).clue: Until 1973 it was known as British Honduras

(1, 2).clue: The Greeks used encomia to praise people; today at a funeral you deliver one of these

(2, 2).clue: In 1974 he became Vermont's first Democrat elected to the U.S. Senate; he's still there

(4, 2).clue: (Sofia is tasting a Mediterranean delicacy.)  This pita contains little balls of this, a deep-fried Mideast treat made from chickpeas or fava beans

(5, 2).clue: Caligula is said to have ordered his alchemists to turn the yellow orpiment, a sulfide of arsenic, into this

(6, 2).clue: It's a road around a town, or an operation to reroute blood

(1, 3).clue: Tongdong, a Korean Pyolgok-form poem, is an ode on the 4 of these

(2, 3).clue: At 4,393 feet, Mount Mansfield in this range is the state's highest point

(4, 3).clue: (Sofia is enjoying a foreign potato product.)  From the Ukranian for "dumpling", it's the name of the potato product I'm eating

(5, 3).clue: Around 3500 B.C. people were mixing copper & arsenic to make this: they soon found copper & tin worked better

(6, 3).clue: It's the historic linen seen here

(1, 4).clue: The Cielito, "darling", is associated with this cowboy literature of Argentina & Uruguay

(2, 4).clue: This city's annual Battle Day Parade commemorates a Revolutionary War battle that took place on August 16, 1777

(4, 4).clue: (Sofia holds up a slice of thin-crust pizza.)  You can get pizza New York-style or in this thicker style named for an Italian island

(5, 4).clue: Gallium arsenide is used in  the semiconductor type of this device found in CD players

(6, 4).clue: An athletic competition combining skiing & shooting

(1, 5).clue: Popular in the 14th century, the Englyn & the Cywydd were poetic forms in this language

(2, 5).clue: The town of Barre is a world center in the production of this stone used for monuments

(4, 5).clue: (Sofia wraps up our taste of the Big Apple--with a stomache--and a bottle of a well-known product for curing such.)  Fortunately, also available in New York is this Procter & Gamble tummy-soothing liquid

(5, 5).clue: "Arsenic and Old Lace" recommends a teaspoon of arsenic per gallon of this wine

(6, 5).clue: (A Renaissance artist, or the intellectual game Cheryl & Jimmy are playing)Cheryl: P.Jimmy: Is it the founder of a colony?Cheryl: No, it's not William Penn.

(1, 1).clue: Hillel phrased this "precious" rule negatively, saying don't do to others what you wouldn't want done to you

(2, 1).clue: This beloved Broadway show was based on a comic strip by Harold Gray

(3, 1).clue: In 1891 a Japanese inventor powered a model plane with one of these office supplies & it flew a reported 33 feet

(4, 1).clue: In 1894 George Kinney began his chain of stores selling these

(5, 1).clue: Representative Thaddeus Stevens led the attempt to impeach this  president

(1, 2).clue: A Florida city is named for this medieval author of "The City of God"

(3, 2).clue: Alberto Santos-Dumont's first flight of his No.1 airship in 1898 ended with it being caught in one of these

(4, 2).clue: By 1845, with John Young & J.L. Ellis, this NYC jeweler switched from selling paste jewels to real

(5, 2).clue: "Big Red" could also have been the nickname of this "man of the people", seen here

(1, 3).clue: Parmenides, Mr. One Unchanging Reality, was a major thinker pre-this man born around 470 B.C.

(3, 3).clue: In 1899 Wilbur Wright asked this museum complex for any info on flying; they sent him some pamphlets

(4, 3).clue: Attention, shoppers -- Borders Books once belonged to this major discount retailer

(5, 3).clue: This president seen here won the Nobel Peace Prize during his term

(1, 4).clue: Expelled from Germany in 1849, he lived his last 30 years in the British kapital

(3, 4).clue: In 1897 3 Swedes (partly funded by Alfred Nobel) tried to reach this point on Earth by balloon -- they died

(4, 4).clue: In 1893 George Brown & this man formed a partnership in Winston-Salem, North Carolina

(5, 4).clue: This "cat", seen here, served as president for only 6 months

(1, 5).clue: Jacques Lacan revised this philosopher's idea as "Where I think, 'I think, therefore I am', that is where I am not"

(2, 5).clue: Ingmar Bergman's movie "Smiles of a Summer Night" inspired this Stephen Sondheim musical

(3, 5).clue: This count was granted a patent in 1895 for his new method of rigid-airship construction

(4, 5).clue: In 1959 a company in this state got the rights to L'Ecran Magique, the Magic Writer, & renamed it the Etch-A-Sketch

(5, 5).clue: This president was described as a "non-entity with sidewhiskers" & "first in ability on the list of second-rate men"

(0, 0).clue: One of the world's bestselling novelists, he created TV's "I Dream of Jeannie"
